solution_line_template: First find the weekly cost of the first employee: ${employee1_hourly_rate}/hour * {hours_per_week} hours/week = $<<{employee1_hourly_rate}*{hours_per_week}={employee1_weekly_cost}>>{employee1_weekly_cost}/week

Then find the hourly cost of the second employee after the government subsidy: ${employee2_hourly_rate_before_subsidy}/hour - ${government_subsidy_per_hour}/hour = $<<{employee2_hourly_rate_before_subsidy}-{government_subsidy_per_hour}={employee2_hourly_cost_after_subsidy}>>{employee2_hourly_cost_after_subsidy}/hour

Then find the weekly cost of the second employee: ${employee2_hourly_cost_after_subsidy}/hour * {hours_per_week} hours/week = $<<{employee2_hourly_cost_after_subsidy}*{hours_per_week}={employee2_weekly_cost}>>{employee2_weekly_cost}/week

Then subtract the smaller weekly cost from the bigger weekly cost to find the difference: ${employee1_weekly_cost}/week - ${employee2_weekly_cost}/week = $<<{employee1_weekly_cost}-{employee2_weekly_cost}={weekly_savings}>>{weekly_savings}/week
